paragraphs.text:
%md
# Analyzing network intrusion dataset with Python and Spark
### By [Saptak Sen](http://saptak.in)
---

### Introduction

In this tutorial we are going to analyze a network intrusion events dataset with **Python** in a Zeppelin Notebook. The Zeppelin Notebook provides an easy and interactive surface for data scientists to explore data through data processing engines like **Hive** and **Spark**. Hive and Spark in turn benefit from robust managability, resource allocation policies, security and scalability running on a YARN managed infrasturcture.

```
                                                                  ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓
                                                                  ┃                     ┃
                                                                  ┃      Executer       ┃
           ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────▶┃     Cache, Task     ┃
           │                                                      ┃                     ┃
           │                                                      ┃                     ┃
           │                                                      ┗━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┛
           │
           │
           │
┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓          ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓          ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃                     ┃          ┃                     ┃          ┃                     ┃
┃       Driver        ┃          ┃   Cluster Manager   ┃          ┃      Executer       ┃
┃    Spark Context    ┃─────────▶┃       (YARN)        ┃─────────▶┃     Cache, Task     ┃
┃                     ┃          ┃                     ┃          ┃                     ┃
┃                     ┃          ┃                     ┃          ┃                     ┃
┗━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┛          ┗━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┛          ┗━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┛
           │
           │
           │
           │                                                      ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓
           │                                                      ┃                     ┃
           │                                                      ┃      Executer       ┃
           └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────▶┃     Cache, Task     ┃
                                                                  ┃                     ┃
                                                                  ┃                     ┃
                                                                  ┗━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┛
```

### Resilient Distributed Dataset
The key concept in Spark are RDDs or Resilient Distributed Datasets.RDD is a fault-tolerant collection of elements that can be operated on in parallel.
 

### Spark Application
A typical Spark application has the following four phases:

```
┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃                       ┃
┃      Instantiate      ┃
┃      Input RDDs       ┃
┃                       ┃
┗━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┛
            │
            │
┏━━━━━━━━━━━▼━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃                       ┃
┃    Transform RDDs     ┃
┃                       ┃
┃                       ┃
┗━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┛
            │
            │
┏━━━━━━━━━━━▼━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃                       ┃
┃        Persist        ┃
┃   Intermediate RDDs   ┃
┃                       ┃
┗━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┛
            │
            │
┏━━━━━━━━━━━▼━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃                       ┃
┃    Action on RDDs     ┃
┃                       ┃
┃                       ┃
┗━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┛
```

### Commenting with Markdown

This block of comments and instructions is formatted as [Markdown](https://help.github.com/articles/github-flavored-markdown/). Every block of code or comments in Zeppelin is also often referred to as a paragraph. 

A block formatted as markdown can be specified when we start the block with `%md`. Any block is executed and rendered when we click the play button on the top-left-hand corner of a block.

### Downloading the Data with Shell commands

In the next block of code we are going to download the data using shell commands. The shell command in a Zeppelin notebook can be invoked when we prepend the block of shell commands with a line containing the characters `%sh`.

Downloading the Data with Shell commands

In the next block of code we are going to download the data using shell commands. The shell command in a Zeppelin notebook can be invoked when we prepend the block of shell commands with a line containing the characters %sh.

paragraphs.text:
%sh

#remove existing copies of dataset from HDFS
hadoop fs -rm  /tmp/kddcup.data_10_percent.gz

#Download the data and pace it into the /tmp folder of Hortonworks Sandbox
wget http://kdd.ics.uci.edu/databases/kddcup99/kddcup.data_10_percent.gz -O /tmp/kddcup.data_10_percent.gz

#Copy the data to HDFS on Hortonworks Sandbox
hadoop fs -put /tmp/kddcup.data_10_percent.gz /tmp

#Verify the data has been copied to the /tmp folder on HDFS
hadoop fs -ls -h /tmp/kddcup.data_10_percent.gz

#Remove the dataset /tmp folder on the Sandbox local filesystem now that the data has been copied to HDFS
rm  /tmp/kddcup.data_10_percent.gz

%md
### Using Scala function calls to fetch environment variables

In the next code block we are using function calls in Scala to fetch environment information. To specify a code block as Scala it is enough to just start the code block with `%spark` 

Whether you are programming in Scala or Python the important thing to notice is the `sc` object better know as SparkContext.
SparkContext is created by your driver program in this case Zeppelin and Pyspark. We will use the SparkContext to further instantiate RDDs in the next section.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Creating RDDs

Below we create a RDD by calling the textFile function on the SparkContext and passing the HDFS path to the raw datset. You can also create RDDs from:

  * JDBC
  * Cassandra
  * HBase
  * Elasticsearch
  * JSON, CSV, sequence files, object files, ORC, Parquet, Avro

The code block below starts with `%pyspark` which indicates we are going to use the Python programming language to interact with Spark. Also for the rest of the tutorial we will continue to use PySpark.

When we execute the next section of the code block to create the RDDs we will notice that it executes super fast. The reason it executes super fast is because it actually does not touch the data yet. You can continue to apply various transformation operations on this RDD and still it will not touch the data, but only construct a DAG or a Directed Acyclic Graph.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### RDD Actions

In the next code block we will count the number of lines in the file by calling the count function on the RDD. Count function on a RDD is a Action operation, which means Spark and YARN will be forced to allocate resource and execute the DAG it has been creating to calculate the result. We will notice that the next code block takes a little longer to run than the previous one for that reason.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Inspect what the data looks like

msg.data: Inspect what the data looks like

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

from pprint import pprint

csv_rdd = raw_rdd.map(lambda x: x.split(","))

head_rows = csv_rdd.take(5)

pprint(head_rows[0])

%pyspark

def parse_interaction(line):
    elems = line.split(",")
    tag = elems[41]
    return (tag, elems)
    
key_csv_rdd = raw_rdd.map(parse_interaction)
head_rows = key_csv_rdd.take(5)
pprint(head_rows[0])

%md
### Using collect() on the Spark driver

msg.data: Using collect() on the Spark driver

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Extracting a smaller sample of the RDD

msg.data: Extracting a smaller sample of the RDD

result.msg: Extracting a smaller sample of the RDD

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

raw_data_local_sample = raw_rdd.takeSample(False, 1000, 1234)

normal_data_sample = [x.split(",") for x in raw_data_local_sample if "normal." in x]

normal_data_sample_size = len(normal_data_sample)

normal_ratio = normal_data_sample_size/1000.0

print(normal_ratio)

%pyspark

services = csv_rdd.map(lambda x: x[2]).distinct()
print services.collect()

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Filtering
Filtering out the normal and attack events

msg.data:
Filtering

Filtering out the normal and attack events

result.msg:
Filtering

Filtering out the normal and attack events

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

normal_csv_data = csv_rdd.filter(lambda x: x[41]=="normal.")
attack_csv_data = csv_rdd.filter(lambda x: x[41]!="normal.")

%pyspark

normal_duration_data = normal_csv_data.map(lambda x: int(x[0]))
total_normal_duration = normal_duration_data.reduce(lambda x, y: x + y)
print(total_normal_duration)

attack_duration_data = attack_csv_data.map(lambda x: int(x[0]))
total_attack_duration = attack_duration_data.reduce(lambda x, y: x + y)
print(total_attack_duration)

%md

### Using Aggregate functions to calulate mean in one pass

msg.data: Using Aggregate functions to calulate mean in one pass

result.msg: Using Aggregate functions to calulate mean in one pass

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

normal_sum_count = normal_duration_data.aggregate(
    (0,0), # the initial value
    (lambda acc, value: (acc[0] + value, acc[1] + 1)), # combine val/acc
    (lambda acc1, acc2: (acc1[0] + acc2[0], acc1[1] + acc2[1]))
)

print(round(normal_sum_count[0]/float(normal_sum_count[1]),3))

attack_sum_count = attack_duration_data.aggregate(
    (0,0), # the initial value
    (lambda acc, value: (acc[0] + value, acc[1] + 1)), # combine value with acc
    (lambda acc1, acc2: (acc1[0] + acc2[0], acc1[1] + acc2[1])) # combine accumulators
)

print(round(attack_sum_count[0]/float(attack_sum_count[1]),3))

%md
### Using reduceByKey to group and aggregate

msg.data: Using reduceByKey to group and aggregate

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

key_value_duration = csv_rdd.map(lambda x: (x[41], float(x[0]))) 
durations_by_key = key_value_duration.reduceByKey(lambda x, y: x + y)

print(durations_by_key.collect())

msg.data: Using countByKey on a key-value RDD

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Using combineByKey to get duration and attempts by type in a single pass from a key-value RDD

msg.data: Using combineByKey to get duration and attempts by type in a single pass from a key-value RDD

result.msg: Using combineByKey to get duration and attempts by type in a single pass from a key-value RDD

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

sum_counts = key_value_duration.combineByKey(
    (lambda x: (x, 1)), # the initial value, with value x and count 1
    (lambda acc, value: (acc[0]+value, acc[1]+1)), # how to combine a pair value with the accumulator: sum value, and increment count
    (lambda acc1, acc2: (acc1[0]+acc2[0], acc1[1]+acc2[1])) # combine accumulators
)

print(sum_counts.collectAsMap())

%pyspark

duration_means_by_type = sum_counts.map(lambda (key,value): (key, round(value[0]/value[1],3))).collectAsMap()

# Print them sorted
for tag in sorted(duration_means_by_type, key=duration_means_by_type.get, reverse=True):
    print(tag, duration_means_by_type[tag])

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
from pyspark.sql import Row

row_data = csv_rdd.map(lambda p: Row(
    duration=int(p[0]), 
    protocol_type=p[1],
    service=p[2],
    flag=p[3],
    src_bytes=int(p[4]),
    dst_bytes=int(p[5])
    )
)

interactions_df = sqlContext.createDataFrame(row_data)
interactions_df.createOrReplaceTempView("interactions")

%md

paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT duration, dst_bytes FROM interactions WHERE protocol_type = 'tcp' AND duration > 1000 AND dst_bytes = 0

%md

### Calculating a derived column on a DataFrame

msg.data: Calculating a derived column on a DataFrame

result.msg: Calculating a derived column on a DataFrame

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

def get_label_type(label):
    if label!="normal.":
        return "attack"
    else:
        return "normal"
    
row_labeled_data = csv_rdd.map(lambda p: Row(
    duration=int(p[0]), 
    protocol_type=p[1],
    service=p[2],
    flag=p[3],
    src_bytes=int(p[4]),
    dst_bytes=int(p[5]),
    label=get_label_type(p[41])
    )
)
interactions_labeled_df = sqlContext.createDataFrame(row_labeled_data)
